webTitle: UK seaside resorts: then and now - in pictures

fields.standfirst:
Seaside resorts across Britain attracted thousands of holidaymakers in their heyday, but these coastal towns have faded, with the former grandeur serving only as a reminder of a glorious bygone era.

Seaside towns around the country are being rejuvenated in the hope they can bring back visitors. Margate's Dreamland amusement park was given £10m last week to transform it into a heritage-themed park. Similar renovation projects are taking place in Blackpool, Morecambe and Bexhill-on-Sea.

Guardian readers share their images of seaside towns during their heyday, in their ruin or after receiving a new lease of life.
fields.headline: UK seaside resorts: then and now - in pictures

tags.bio:
Eric Allison is the Guardian's prison correspondent.

He was born in Manchester, 1942, the youngest of four boys. His first conviction was for housebreaking when he was 11 and, at 14, he received his first custodial sentence. Three months in a detention centre was intended to provide a "short sharp shock" to deter him but instead he met up with virtually every member of the "class of 57" during his criminal/penal journey, which ended in 2000. Eric Allison has spent some 16 years in prison, all for theft related offences. During that time he quickly became appalled at the bad treatment handed out to people who had not "chosen" crime as a career and witnessed acts of brutality and racism on an almost daily basis. As a result he decided to speak out and took action against the abuse. He discovered that the adage "the pen is mightier … " proved particularly accurate in prison and, following the Strangeways Prison Riot, in 1990, he co-authored a book on the protest, A Serious Disturbance. The book was used by several education authorities as A-level course work (Sociology). In 2003 Eric Allison joined the Guardian as the prison correspondent.

Helen Pidd is northern editor of the Guardian, based in Manchester. She joined the paper in 2004 to edit the now defunct Office Hours and was a commissioning editor on G2 before joining the home news team in 2007, going on to spend 2011 in Germany as Berlin correspondent followed by a stint in Delhi. She is the author of Bicycle – The Complete
Guide to Everyday Cycling.

webTitle: Colorado wildfire quickly destroys hundreds of homes – in pictures

fields.standfirst: The Black Forest wildfire near Colorado Springs has spread quickly since igniting on Tuesday afternoon. By Friday firefighters said they had battled the blaze to a 'draw', keeping it in place despite swirling winds and dry weather. At least two people have been killed, discovered Thursday in the garage of their home. Nearly 40,000 people are under evacuation orders, and the fire has already burned at least 360 homes, making it the most destructive in Colorado history
fields.headline: Colorado wildfire quickly destroys hundreds of homes – in pictures
fields.trailText: The Black Forest wildfire near Colorado Springs has spread quickly since igniting on Tuesday afternoon, and by Friday firefighters said they had battled the blaze to a 'draw'. At least two people have been killed, discovered Thursday in the garage of their home.

webTitle: Syria: no-fly zone is not a ‘silver bullet’, says White House – video

fields.standfirst: Ben Rhodes, deputy national security adviser, discusses military support for the Syrian oppisition at a White House breifing on Friday, following US confirmation that Syrian government forces have used chemical weapons against the rebels. Rhodes says setting up a no-fly zone over Syria would not be easy. Moscow, who would veto such a move, has rejected the US claims over chemical weapon use, but Rhodes insists that it is in Russia's best interest to put pressure on president Bashar al-Assad to step down
fields.headline: Syria: no-fly zone is not a ‘silver bullet’, says White House – video

Helen Pidd is northern editor of the Guardian, based in Manchester. She joined the paper in 2004 to edit the now defunct Office Hours and was a commissioning editor on G2 before joining the home news team in 2007, going on to spend 2011 in Germany as Berlin correspondent followed by a stint in Delhi. She is the author of Bicycle – The Complete
Guide to Everyday Cycling.

tags.bio: Dan Roberts is the Guardian's Washington Bureau chief, covering politics and US national affairs. Previously, he worked as the national editor in London and was head of business. Follow him on Twitter @robertsdan
Angelique Chrisafis is the Guardian's Paris correspondent
Miriam Elder is The Guardian's Moscow correspondent

Richard Norton-Taylor regularly contributes to BBC news and current affairs programmes. He writes for The Guardian on defence and security and until recently was the paper's security editor. He won the Freedom of Information Campaign Award for journalism in 1986. He edits the Guardian Defence and Security blog with Nick Hopkins.

Email him at: richard.norton-taylor [at] guardian.co.uk
